Living Desert Zoo & Gardens.name: Living Desert Zoo & Gardens
reviews: Fun day - Easy walk and more than enough to see!

This was our first visit to the Living Desert Zoo and Gardens. It is a great zoo and botanical gardens. There was a lot to see in the couple of hours that we were there, but we did not feel we missed out on anything and could have explored further if we really wanted to.
Show less

A cool, blustery day kept me off the golf course and I reluctantly succumbed to my better halves suggestion to go to the Living Desert.

It is WONDERFUL. The staff is excellent and was helpful with our questions. The layout is absolutely wonderful and easily accessible and the map facilitated our travels through the Desert.

The animals are literally "right there" and, contrary to so many other "zoos" are contained in areas that actually appear to be humane.

The camel ride is a bit of a novelty as is the bird feeding area. The signage throughout the Desert as pertains to the animals as well as the flora and fauna is exceptional.

We had a great time and look forward to returning!
Show less
Camel rides, giraffe feeding, lorikeets all over you trying to lick nectar from the small cups. The train setup they have is awesome. Bring a lot of water and use sunscreen.

Very simply a great place to visit... even without children. Much larger than I expected this is a worthwhile Sunday afternoon place to go in my estimation. Spent about three hours there and really enjoyed the experience. Highly recommend if you like the outdoors and very detailed explanations....
Show less
You mean there is life in a Desert?
If you think this way, you are in for a life changing experience. From plants to animals, birds, water and humans the desert has it all. Truly a life of it's own.
Even for a 1 & 2 year old, a fun day!

Look for a cooler day, which we had, but there are a lot of trees for shade. There are uncovered strollers but only two wagons which hold two children. Get those early, but they are uncovered. Feeding the giraffes is a hit! Petting the goats another hit. See the cheetahs up close where the glass is but get there early. They trot between two feeding attendants at each end of their pastured area as they blow their whistle so where the benches are, they are moving. Luckily, we witnessed the kookaburra laughing, and there were plenty of other sites to see. The kids loved the carousel, and for a $2 ride, it was worth the experience for a couple of times each. Spent about half a day there, till the kids , and we, were tired. Can easily go back to do / see more again. Very great place to take kids in strollers. Cement is wide and lots to see and do!
Show less

We visited this zoo recently while on vacation in Palm Desert. I usually have mixed feelings about zoos - but this one does an excellent job with natural habitats. It’s worth the admission price just to see the giraffes. Right now they have 8 giraffes on park and you can get really up close and personal. For a small fee you can feed them between the hours of 9:30 and 2:30. The kids really seemed the enjoy that and the giraffe was so gentle. We spent about two hours here and were able to walk the whole park at a leisurely pace. All of the animals looked very well cared for and the staff was very friendly and accommodating. There is a shuttle that you can use for a small fee and it seems very helpful for older visitors or those with restricted mobility. We would definitely recommend a visit here.
Show less

The Living Desert is a conservation and preservation park that educates the public about threatened animal and plant species.
It has interactive animal exhibits such as giraffe and bird feeding as well as camel rides.
The park has beautiful walking paths that meander between the African and North American exhibits. There are several benches and drinking fountains along the pathways which are great on a hot day.
We love visiting the Living Desert and learn something new every time we go!

Show less

Had great time, exhibits were outstanding. Animals & plants were very nive & varied a lot. Educational, fun, & creative. Plan on at least 4-5 hrs. You could easily spend more time easily. Sunscreen a must have!

The Living Desert Zoo was certainly more than we were expecting. Although it is not large by other zoo comparables (Seattle and San Diego) it has a very visible charm and sense of place. The zoo prides itself on taking great care of it's animals which is evident by the roomy and well thought out enclosures. They also have a fully staffed and outfitted surgery which allows them to give all of the animals regular check ups and "repairs" when needed. They take great pride in doing their part in managing these captivity raised animals both in the present and future. Highlights include the jaguars, cheetahs and the wonderful giraffes.
Show less

One of the better zoos with the animals (understandably excepting reptiles and birds) given plenty of room to roam freely. The distant mountains and palm-studded grounds provide especially beautiful backgrounds for the giraffes, and it's always great fun watching the meerkats. Small gardens tucked along the winding paths are filled with local desert plants. Despite a full parking lot, the gardens never seemed crowded. Probably not the best destination during Palm Springs' blazing hot summers.
Show less
We were absolutely delighted with a wonderful, guided nature walk by one of the educated and friendly volunteers. Go early and enjoy!
Family visited from Orange County. Went to Living Desert to see Christmas Decorations. We had multiple pictures with Great Santa and children were excited to feed the Reindeers.

This natural setting was what we liked about this zoo, that and the animals. We went to see the Christmas lights but since they had select days for the show we ended up missing them. We wanted to experience the Xmas lights so went later to the living zoo which was our fault, about 3pm and the zoo was closing at 5pm. We did rush through because of time but enjoyed the animals we did see. Lots of walking but you could take the tram cars for a price, all in all would definitely recommend a visit here.
Show less

The Living Desert provided an entertaining and interesting place to visit for our family - ages from 1 to over 50. Kept us amused all afternoon. A good variety of animals, cheetahs and giraffes were highlights for us, and a small petting zoo.

We read that people thought two hours would be enough for this place, but for us four hours wasn't enough. The variety of animals was amazing -- one part had North American animals, the other part African. You can get up close to the giraffes when they come to feed, and it was remarkable to be a couple of feet from a cheetah during a training exercise. The focus on preserving animals here and in the wild was inspiring. The volunteers were very knowledgeable about the animals -- they seem to specialize in particular areas and get to know the animals' personalities. The staff presentations were also very interesting. We did not take the tram at all; just moved at a relaxed pace. We were enchanted.
Show less

Volunteers are mostly retirees who just love what they do and are willing to help with anything. The desert brings a natural feeling to this zoo. Great place for kids and adults. We went to feed the giraffes and couldn't believe they took their carrots right out of your hand, softly and gently. You can also pet some very happy furry goats. The park is divided in continents and the animals seem content and happy to meet their handlers. There is a beautiful merry-go-round. They have little trains for those who can't walk but walking is best as you meander through the different areas, often under tree canopies. Just beautiful.
Show less
One of the best Zoos I have been to! I couldn't believe I didn't discover this zoo until recently. Huge grounds and you can get up close to the animals! The kids loved it. I highly recommend it!

Sometimes difficult walking,not level. Have to come early to see the animals in action. There are some extra options such as feeding the giraffe but these are extra charges. There is a train that goes around, on and off, $6.00 per person. It explains what you are looking at. Can get hot in the middle of the day.
Show less
Relaxing stroll with plenty to see
Bring your walking shoes and take plenty of water. The stroll is uphill and then back down. Along the way, plenty of exhibits and animals in natural habitats. Well worth the visit.

Wonderful place to spend a few hours with or without the kids. Great value for your money. Even has 3/4 of an acre dedicated to working model trains. Has lots of animals at the zoo. You can feed the Lorakeet birds and go on a carousel.
Show less

The animals are so awesome. The camels and giraffes completely different in real life, the colors and lines on the giraffes beautiful, their long toungues wow! The park is well laid out and very desert landscaped. Lots of places n the shade to sit and just observe the animals.
Show less

Brought my wife and son with an intention to kill five hours between timeshare check-ins. We lived in the Middle East several years and expected similar zoo exhibits. It was comparable, but surprisingly (based on city size) this was better. Parking lot was already nearly full by the time we arrived in late morning. There was a model railway I could have spent hours with. Several exhibits were highly interactive including a great bird feeding experience and giraffe feeding opportunity. We were entertained our entire time at this zoo and would definitely return.
Show less

We are spending more time in PD this year. We joined with a dual membership for $99 of which $75 was tax deductible. 2 persons free for a year, 2 one time admissions, $12 additional daily tickets, and a number of other benefits. Well worth it if you’re gong to visit more than once a season. Really lovely garden setting and lots of animals. Keeper talks at designated times. We didn’t go this time - we have in the past- but there’s a very nice hike, which can involve some rock scrambling a bit to the east. The Living Desert opens earlier for members. Nice gift shop on site.
Show less

We went to the living desert in the morning and spent at least five hours there. It gets pretty warm in the afternoon so a few morning trips might be enjoyable. The animals tend to rest in the heat. There is places to rest and sit in the shade if needed. You are able to get a private tour if you want but they sell out quickly. We were able to see the feeding of a cheetah. On their website it shows what talks are available and you can even see operations. The gardens are lovely different types for different areas of a desert region. There is a couple of restaurants on sight for a bite to eat. They do sell beer. It was well worth the 18.00 dollars. You can get an annual pass if you want! Very interesting loved it! Would go several times if we came here again.
Show less

Spent a great day touring the zoo on wide and stable pathways. Lots of shade available. The gardens were impressive and well cared for. Lots of displays and different animals. The giraffes are a hit - especially the new baby! So cute. The park is divided and clearly marked into two regions - North America and Africa. The hospital tour was informative and interesting.
Great family place!
Show less

It was our first time in Palm Springs and we were travelling with some friends that wanted to hit a casino. Hubby and I are zoo/animal lovers, so we opted to spend the afternoon outside at the Living Desert. A little background, we are zoological members with the Milwaukee County Zoo in WI (a great zoo if you ever get in the area) and hubby travels all over for his business so likes to check out the local zoos whenever he can.

Maybe we weren't expecting all that much, but we were very impressed!!! First off, there is a large train display set up as you enter the zoo. Fun to walk around and check it all out. We then proceeded to make our way thru and saw animals we had never seen or heard of before. I loved the "coziness" of the zoo and the landscaping. We only had a few hours to take it all in, but it was such a great afternoon. Loved our time here. I got some great photo's of the giraffe's standing up on a hill. So different than the zoos we have been to before.

I hope to one day return and spend more time here.
Show less

We were greeted within moments of arriving by a very kind docent/volunteer.
Knowledgable and helpful.
We got a late start this morning so missed a few opportunities to see some of the scheduled xxxxxxx.
We walked the entire grounds and were so impressed by the care of the animals and beautiful plants.
We stopped at the animal hospital where they allow you to see some procedures through a viewing area when they are taking place. We did not see any. Another female docent greeted us and patiently explained all the info about the hospital and how it operates.
Despite the unseasonably warm weather most of the animals were visible. Some sleeping. We still saw animals we have never seen before even at the San Diego Zoo. We wish we had purchased a membership!
I am not a big fan of zoos. This was exceptional.
Show less
Unforgettable Guest Activities --Feed a Giraffe, Ride a Camel, Feed Lorikeets

The Living Desert offers a number of options for guests to interact with zoo residents for a more memorable experience with an additional fee. Great photos and videos can be taken up close when feeding a giraffe or the Lorikeets or riding a Camel. The cheetah run show is free and provides a perfect opportunity to see them in action. The best time to go is early morning to see more animals active and possibly being fed. We paid an extra $6 for the shuttle service since one person in our group had a bad knee and it was great for getting from one area to another in the heat as well. As soon as we arrived, we took the shuttle all the way around to get an overview of all the areas from the driver and it only took 15 minutes. Each shuttle stop had shaded benches as well for us to rest while we waited to be picked up.
Show less

I was a bit disappointed, as I often am at zoos. During the mid day sun, the animals are not particularly active. I saw a lot of empty cages, and sleeping animals.
Show less

I hadn't been to the Living Desert for about twenty years. When last here it was mostly a desert oriented botanical garden with a few fauna exhibits. The animal exhibits have been greatly expanded (into a real zoo) while maintaining the interesting collection of desert plants, etc. On a week day during the school year, the place wasn't crowded at all. We had a leisurely stroll through the park and really enjoyed both the plants and animals. We particularly liked the Lorikeet house and the Giraffe area. The giant outdoor model train set may be a bit out dated, but it's still lots of fun. January is a perfect time: sunny but not too hot.
Show less
Both interesting and educational for all ages

I am not usually one to go to a zoo but this place is so much more than just a zoo. And as my title says this site was so interesting and educational, and we are 2 middle-aged, animal-loving adults with no children. We had visited and enjoyed a place similar to this in Tucson so we decided to give this place a go too and it was great fun, especially learning about and seeing the large variety of African animals we had only seen before on TV.
Some of our favourite animals to see in the flesh were the cheetahs, the giraffes, and the zebras to name just a few.
To learn about this zoo's conservation and preservation efforts for so many different animals was truly inspiring. And, to learn that a portion of each entrance fee goes towards saving endangered animal species, among many other animal-related things, made our visit that much more enjoyable.
I can't imagine anyone not enjoying a visit here, so be sure to check this place out if you are in the greater Palm Springs area.....but don't just take my word for it, visit this zoo's website to see everything it has to offer.
Show less
A gem of a combination botanical garden and zoo

We had visited here over 30 years ago with our children but it was still interesting for us now. I loved how the desert plants were labeled. There is a section on North American animals and African animals along with plants that would be in those areas. Butterfly and Hummingbird gardens as well as aviaries, snakes, bighorn sheep, camels, giraffes, etc. are all in very natural settings. We saw cheetahs racing, giraffes being fed and children riding camels. We also took a walk on a nature trail out into the desert to a lookout to view the San Andreas Fault.
Show less

They have done a excellent job developing this animal park. The giraffe area is one of the best we have visited. You can feed the giraffes and a great photo opportunity. Great Desert setting against the mountains makes for a perfect blend of landscapes. Lots of shade, resting areas and picnic areas. If you plan on more then one visit the annual pass is a good value. Costco also sells the daily pass at an discounted price, about $14.00 saving for two people. Lots of refreshment spots in the park. The desert cactus and trees are identified along the paths which is educational as well. Five stars to the park volunteers as they are eager to help(very knowledgeable) and we were directed to the cheetah run just in time to see these beautiful animals. You can take hikes from here as well. You can visit the animal hospital on site, the only one of its kind open to public. We will be returning in about 6 weeks with family and sampling the ice cream again.
Show less
One of the best zoo's we have ever been to. Great care of the animals and such a wonderful variety and very rare animals that you don't see at other zoos

visited the Living Desert with my grand children and they loved it. Beautiful grounds and wonderful representation of our desert. Very friendly and helpful volunteers trough-out the grounds. Great little tram to take us around and the tickets are good all day. Animal hospital volunteer gave us a nice little informative tour. Purchased the unlimited children's ticket for the camel ride, the Giraffe feeding and the Lorikeets aviary. They couldn't get enough of feeding the lovely colorful birds and feeding the Giraffes. Best bargain for $17.95. We're already planning another visit later this year.
Show less

We wanted to see more of the gardens with plant designations. Not all labeled-seemed to lack care. Not a complete zoo but a nice walk through
Show less
A wonderful zoo in a pristine setting.
We were a large group so we took the tram ride around the grounds. The tour guide/driver was very knowledgeable and the animals are easy to see in a wonderful setting.
We enjoyed the native plants. This zoo is serene. We loved seeing the mountain goats and giraffes. Great place to take pix of animals. We definitely will return.

This garden has it all--plants, animals, model train exhibit, good restaurant, shuttles, lots of free parking. The shuttle pass is a bargain--on-off stops throughout the park, lots of interpretive talks along the way by drivers.

Great place to take the young ones my daughter wasn’t old enough but she still enjoyed her time and I had a lot of great memories the last time I was there I was 5yrs old... LOVED IT
Show less

It is always a treat to go to the Living Desert! Each time is a different experience. The desert plants create a peaceful and harmonious environment and the animals along the way are such a fun and exquisite treat at the same time. Highly recommend!!
A day at the Living Desert

This is a really nice place to spend a day, It is a zoo, but many of the animals are in open pens instead of cages. The Hop-on/Hop off tram is well worth the ticket price(extra from admission ticket), as this is a large park, and you may want to go around more than once. Dress for the weather, all trails and pens are out in the open. Timing your visit to take advantage of feeding times is worth the effort.
Show less

This is one of the best attractions in the Palm Spring-Palm Desert Area. It is divided into two areas: North America and Africa. We paid the extra $6 for tram tickets. As we rode the tram, the driver gave an overview of the Zoo. You and get off and on at any stop.

We arrived at the cheetahs just before 11:15 AM. They are fed once daily at 11:15 so we were just in time. There are four ‘girls’ there and they are magnificent. They are trained to run between feeding locations. Although they cannot reach their full speed they are very exciting to watch as they run, walk, and lie in the shade.

There are many other fine exhibits and activities. You can feed the giraffes, ride a camel and much more. This was one of our special highlights during our month in this area. Don’t miss it.
Show less
Best views of wild animals I've been to

My family and I really enjoyed our visit at the Living Desert! Loved the fun shows and the education they provided. The Giraffe feeding was amazing and we were so close to them. So many desert plants and cactus to see and learn about too.
Awesome for families and small children

Wow! I was presently surprised. This place exceeded my expectations. I went today with my 11month son and my parents. We got there at 1pm and stayed till closing (5pm). We had time to do the full map quickly and see most exhibits. They have a big variety of animals and the site is a nice size. We loved to feed the girafes and checkout the foxes and mexican wolves. We got a 2 for 1 pass for 22$ from Costco online. General admission is about 20$ so that is a great deal. At one point we got hungry and stopped at the main café near the entrace and I got a sandwich (7$) and chili (4,50$) for 11,50$. Pretty good price. The staff was also able to get me hot water for my baby bottle. The washroom I went in was ok...they had a change table. Washroom would need renovating because they look dirty. The petting zoo is simply nigerian goats. It was ok. Would be nice to incorporate more animals. The shows we managed to see were good for young children. I would definitely recommend this place to any family visiting Palm Desert/Springs.
Show less
Very expensive to take the kids!

I took my grandkids and it was very expensive, had to pay to feed the giraffes, paid for camel ride, paid for entrance fee, very disappointed in the lack of animals in the hospital, I have visited many zoos, most of the population was small animal in cages. A waste of time! Sorry I was very disappointed.
Show less

One should make time to visit The Living Desert in Palm Desert! You are given hands on at feeding time! My Grandchildren loved feeding the giraffe! We were able to get photos of them and they still are talking about it.
We prefer to go in the earlier hours before it gets too hot!
Show less
A fun zoo and botanical garden - just the right size

A group of friends visited here last weekend. We LOVED walking, seeing the animals, seeing the plants, and being together. Someone had recommended this place to us -- and we were so glad they did. A fun outing. We were there about 2.5 hours and could have stayed longer, but had a conflict. We fed the lorikeets (very fun), watched the miniature trains (very fun), and enjoyed watching others feed the giraffes. A good walk, easy to get around, no big hills, very accessible. The temperature for us was around 72 degrees -- perfect. However, it think that this would be an uncomfortable place to visit when it is HOT. Glad we went!
Show less

Enough about how wonderful the Living Desert is for all ages. We are members who bring our grandchildren and children as often as they come to visit us. The kids love it, learn something new each trip, and are exhausted by the end of the day; a grandparent's DREAM. But a really special experience is the camel ride. Not so much the camels, who are gentle, sweet and stinky, but the handlers. What kind and patient young men. They make sure the riders enjoy the experience, but also stop to let the happy grandparents take pictures and even snap the greatest shots of camel closeups with the happy riders.. It's a long day leading the animals and these guys made every family feel special.
Show less
We went to the zoo and enjoyed it a lot. We saw the Cheetah run, saw Giraffes, Goats, and other animals. It was a fun morning activity.
Cool place to see animals and good start for nice hike

Not best having to pay to enter zoo and gardens when we only really wanted to go on hike which was very nice, few folks around although some very loud mouth bimbos that could talk forever and carry even further, so nice to get out of their range.
Hike was fun, moderate with great views and reasonably marked.
Spent some time in zoo on way back, some very good parts, did like cheetahs and girrafes.
Show less
Great place to connect with nature

We live about 30 minutes from the Safari Park in San Diego, have stopped going in recent years due to the increase in price and commercialism of the park. The Living Zoo reminds me of what the wild animal Park used to be; A place that is conservation minded with natural habitats. Price is fairly reasonable and there are so many animals to see and hiking trails too. They even offer a giraffe feeding experience. Definitely plan to go when it is cooler because much of the park requires walking and I imagine it can get very hot. We went without kids and based on the amount of children having meltdowns, it was fun as a grown-up date.
Show less

I have been traveling to Palm Springs and the surrounding areas for years, but never visited the Living Desert Zoo and Garden. With its extensive walking paths featuring an amazing array of desert fauna, the extensive assortment of animals in very nice habitat or the wonderful hiking trails, this place has something to please everyone.

It even has a state of the art animal hospital where you can actually tour and watch procedures being done (this was one of the stipulations of Mrs Gates who donated 7 million dollars to build the hospital).

It also has the worlds second largest outdoor toy train exhibit (if you like toy trains, you will be absolutely amazed (I was). Looking for a camel ride, petting zoo, or carousel ride- they have that also.

Plan on spending at least 3 hours (we were there for 4 hours). We like to hike so including the park and hiking we covered about 7.5 Miles.

For those not as mobile they have a tram that will pick you up and drop you around the park anywhere you like during your stay for $6 -they come by every 15 minutes.

This facility has one of the most extensive groups of volunteers and donors I have ever seen. This is truly a community gem strongly supported by the Greater Palm Desert and Palm Springs Community. They have a multi million dollar expansion under way which will make it even better. General Admisson is less than $20 for Adults and Seniors/kids get a nice discount.

This place is a must if you are visiting Palm Springs, Indio, Palm Desert, Cathedral City, La Quinta or anywhere within a 30 mile radius. Take the family, spend the day and enjoy. Definitely one of life’s little pleasures.
Show less
Animals, desert, trains and much more

This place has a lot to offer everyone. For families there are the zoo animals and hikes on the different paths. Lots and lots of different desert fauna from all over the world. Loved the state of the art animal treatment center. We got a tour of the facility by a great volunteer who showed us how the animals were treated including showing us the operating areas. Before leaving we came across the very large garden train lay out (G gauge). If you at are a model train hobbyist this may be your only stop. Lots of places to get snacks and eat around the zoo. You can get discounted tickets beforehand at the Palm Springs Visitors Center same day as your trip. This was one of my favorite days in Palm Springs. One day minimum and possibly 2 days.
Show less

The Living Desert was wonderful and a must when your in Palm Springs I don't know why we hadn't done it before on one of our other trips. It's quite a lengthy and interesting walk through the zoo. From all the animals to the different kinds of vegetation it was very enjoyable. We were able to feed the giraffes and ride a camel, as well as view several different types of animals we had never seen before that were native to the desert climate. We were here for about 3 to 4 hours, lots of fun!
Show less

When in Palm Springs the Living Desert seems to be the first thing that is recommended to do. We got there at opening and spent I think 3-4 hours there. It was a great place. There are lots of animals and neat little side gardens to walk through with cacti and other various plants. The zoo is well laid out. The giraffe feeding was I think $5 extra and you got a decent amount of carrots to feed the giraffes. That was fun and totally worth the extra money. Same thing with the camel rides. Really nice carousal too. I think a ride on that was $2 – it was empty when we got there and I’m pretty sure the lady gave us an extra-long ride. The extra’s do add up but I think they have an extra unlimited package you can add to your admission that groups all the extras so you can do them as many times as you want. They were worth it for us. We had a great time. It’s not a huge zoo – totally do able in a couple of hours but its well laid out and was an enjoyable morning. By the time we left the parking lot was packed so it’s probably good to get there early.
Show less
Beautiful example of the desert with animals

It has been 25 years since I first came here. They have added many new animals in natural surroundings. So, nice to walk around at your own pace. They also offer a tram. Great place to take photos. Gorgeous cactus gardens. I loved the cheetahs, giraffes and you can even take a camel ride.
Show less

Wonderful zoo! Happy animals, happy workers (especially Barbara the shuttle driver!) and happy volunteers. Exotic array of animals and it is a learning experience for both children and adults. Feeding the giraffes was just great and many children opted to feed them carrots also. When feeding got too slow, the giraffes nudged the volunteer on the backto get the food chain moving. It was just plain a great environment with happy and quite content workers and animals. The greenery is wonderful also. It was a wonderful day at the Living Desert Zoo and Gardens.
Show less

What am amazing place! Spent a few hours but definitley could have spent an entire day there! Lots of activities for kids and things to see. The animals were stunning and feeding the giraffes was a highlight!
Show less

This place is awesome during Christmas and if you have kids they would enjoy it. We have been coming here for the past 7 years with my in laws and have made it a tradition and look forward to it every year.
Great outing for all ages....feeding time is fun to see. Volunteers are wonderful...saw the cheetahs eating their meatballs, the giraffes eating the carrots...Cool
Educational zoo experience for the family

Definitely plan for at least a half day to see this hidden gem in the desert. We took our 12 year old daughter and she loved all of it. In addition to the animals you'd typically expect to see in a living desert zoo, this zoo also has a variety of desert gardens throughout the grounds and are well worth extra time spend wandering along the paths. When we were there they also had a Lorikeet Exhibit (right next to the camel rides) where you paid a small amount extra for an entrance fee and additional couple dollars for a cup of nectar. If you're going in I highly recommend at least one of you get the cup of nectar and have someone else with a camera ready to snap photos. It was a very colorful stop on our zoo visit. We also took advantage of the watching the trainers train and work with some of the animals - Cheeta Run, Wild Dog training and an attempt to do target training with the Golden eagle (he was having none of it the day we were there). These 15 minute educational sessions are very well done using positive training methods and providing stimulation for the animals and an opportunity to learn for the visitors. The trainers not only let you watch their training methods but impart fascinating tidbits about the animals and their lifestyles. We also found the volunteers to be very well educated and willing to share information. Don't miss a visit to the animal hospital. They do let the public in for short tours and you might even have an opportunity to see an animal or two in rehab.
Show less
You need at least a full or half day to see it all.

We stopped by here after going to the street fair and didnt realize how much there was to actually see. Only managed to get in the Africa part. we were there after 2pm and most of the animals were lazy . If you want to see them a little more agile, I suggest going in the morning.
Show less
There were animals in the zoo. But what I found astounding was the wealth of flora that can abound in the desert. Those cacti were beautiful, weird, and wonderful.
We enjoyed our visit very much. Some unusual animals for us East Coasters and the giraffe interaction was such a treat!

Small zoo, but expensive. Not worth the admission price for our family. The kids like our home town zoo much better, and it’s cheaper!

We were impressed with the variety of animals, the nice layout and exhibition area and the added attraction of a fabulous train exhibit!

Did a 2 hr tour private tour. The zoo is really nice and there are a bunch of animals and they are very easy to view. Didn’t love that the tour spent about an hour on the botanic garden aspects given that we have kids with us— especially since the guide asked us up front what we wanted to see and we emphasized only animals. Good option if in Palm Springs to view a variety of animals from across the world. Also fun for the kids was feeding the giraffes.

We spent a few hours at the zoo. It has grown over the pst 10 years and is continuing to grow. They have some great educational talks and we loved watching the running of the cheetahs and feeding the giraffes. I would definitely recommend this. Take your own snacks. A bag of chips was $2.50.

Fabulous Zoo! Great for kids and adults!

This was simply a wonderful, although untraditional, zoo. There are not as many animals as a tyipcal zoo, but the animals that are there have far better spaces to roam and seem to be far happier. It is so much more fun to visit a zoo when seeing animals in more "natural" habitats. The giraffes were simply magnificent, as were the mountain sheep! Seeing the "cheetah run" was a lot of fun. We also did one of the hikes which was enjoyable too. Also loved the model train set - so expansive and endless things to look at. Truly impressive!

Many of the carnivores were obviously unhappy in enclosures that are too small - the African hunting dogs, the wolves, the coyotes, even one of the coatis, were all pacing the same paths over and over, which is indicative of stress and boredom (stereotypic behavior is the scientific name for this phenomenon). On the plus side, the grazing animals had more space and the gardens were all very nice, and I liked the petting zoo. Overall would not recommend to friends.

This place is no ordinary zoo—it's a showcase of indigenous desert habitats, both plants and animals that has some exotic animals I've never seen before. I was lucky to be there in the late afternoon for feeding time, which made for fascinating viewing, watching a small cat eat a rat and cheetahs hunt for raw mounds of horse meat that the zookeeper planted in their habitat for them to find. I'd allow around three hours for this beast of a feast. If you're in the area, don't miss it!

The zoo itself is great - fun to see bobcats, wolves, zebras, etc all out and active. However, the set up left much to be desired. We bought our tickets online, and the web site said skip the line and go straight to park entry. But in reality there was no separate line for park entry, and the staff was super unhelpful - really brusque - when we asked where to enter. We had purchased tickets for general admission and also for the holiday lights. We assumed we would just stay for the evening display, but instead we were told we had to leave at 5 and re-enter at 6 for the lights. The staff told us they were overwhelmed with 4,000 plus visitors for the lights the night before. This place is unusual. It is sort of a "zoo," but with many enclosures and "areas" large enough to "simulate" natural habitats for the different animals. Walking is easy along wide paved paths. Everything is "accessible." There is even a "shuttle service" available for those who need it (slight extra cost). The focus is on animals and birds of "desert" areas of our planet. The entire park is well organized along geographical areas of the world. We were there in the winter (December) and it was perfect walking weather. From all indications, Spring might be the best time to visit, due to the profusion of flowering plants (cacti, trees, bushes, succulents all over!). I can imagine how colorful that must be. The only (minor) complaint is that there is a slight extra charge for some special exhibits or activities, like riding a camel or feeding a giraffe. But overall, prices are reasonable for everything. Kids, especially, seemed to enjoy the place very much.

We had visited Living dessert over the summer 4 years ago. The number of animals at the zoo has increased and they seem to enjoy the winter weather more. One of the better small zoos

This place has some cool experiences...camel riding, lorakete feeding and giraffe feeding...all extra. However, they have a great diverse set of animals and it’s big enough to occupy half a day with the kiddos.

An amazing place to visit. Manageable size zoo & gardens. Affordable tram tours available with very knowledgeable guides. Informative, with enough stops for pictures. Giffraths amazing. Extremely large train display. Food was most excellent at Cafe!
Cheetahs, Camels & Giraffes - All in One Day!

There were 13 of us so we boarded the VIP private tour at the gates. Not only did we see the sites that were most important to us, but we were highly entertained by our knowledgeable guide. For groups of 10 or more, this is a great way to get familiar with the park and it's many wonderful animals in their habitats. We saved quite a bit on the regular gate fee with this tour.

The highlight for the youngest in our group was feeding the lorikeets. Be prepared to pay extra for feeding and/or riding the animals.

Plenty of rest area and shady spots. Lots of walking, so wear sturdy shoes, sunscreen and a hat.

We were impressed by the rescue work they do for wounded animals brought to their hospital. All in all, a great day and time well spent!

the living desert started out very small some years ago and has grown into a fabulous attraction. the gardens are lovely and they have many species of animals that are rare to find in any other location. the programs to adopt (care for) animals is wonderful seasonal events are great. it really is a special place for both children and adults.

This is a time of giving, loving those around us. We each day should be great full what we and and help those in need. The wild life s just something else, wonderful for all ages. Brings in the spite of the Holidays.

It was lightly sprinkling so we decided to take our 5 and 6 year old grandchildren to the Living Desert. The kids loved it! They rode a carousel and a camel, fed giraffes and lorikeets. We loved the low key type of attraction and saw more animals than expected. Managed to get some great pictures of cheetahs and giraffes. There is a lot of walking involved but if you wish, for a small additional fee, there is a hop on/off trolley. Well worth a visit.

Be sure to get here for opening time and review the day's schedule so you can make the most of the day.

An activity that is really popular is the cheetah run where 3 sister cheetahs are whistle trained to run around their compound in search of food. There is a commentary on the cheetahs and their life in the jungle. At the end the cheetahs are fed meatballs. We were in the viewing area to the right of the compound and got to see the cheetahs eating right in front of us. There are 2 viewing areas..not sure if the feeding area changes from time to time.

The cheetah feeding was at 11;15am and we we had time to view most of the African display prior to that time.

We also took advantage of the trail that enables you to walk on the San Andreas fault line. There are 3 trails...a very short one over a fraction of a mile, another which is 1.5 miles long and another much harduous trail which we didn't even consider. If you can on hiking be sure to bring a hat, lots of water and a cell phone. You must return by 5pm before the centre closes. The trails expose you to the vegetation and rock formations of the desert.

We finished up the day by going through the N American display and lastly, the various gardens. All and all well worth the admission price.

If you are unable to walk great distances, there are little carts that pick you up and drop you off at various key points all over the grounds.

For a fee, Children will enjoy feeding carrots to the giraffes. We were quite happy watching them being fed from the nearby area. For a fee, you can ride a camel. We were happy to come along as the camel's were being fed and watch them race from one pen to the other to get to their chow.

Another memorable feature of this place is the miniature train display. You must see this and if you have children, be prepared to spend a chunk of time in this area!

The Living Gardens and Zoo is handy to hwy 74 coming into Palm Springs from the south.

This is a great time of year to visit. Go in the afternoon during the day before sunset to see the animals and stay for the Wildlights. The display of lights after sunset is magnificent. The Living Desert is very crowded this time of year but worth the visit and the entrance fee. You can join as a family and get a membership for the year if you plan to visit often. Check the schedule of events and times of operations prior to your visit. There is also a great hiking trail within the grounds that is great to explore. They provide a map but ask specifically about the hiking trail and location if that is something you are interested in.

Beautiful and inspiring place to spend the morning.

So much to see and experience. Be sure to allow several hours to explore. The docents are friendly and full of information - so be sure to ask questions about the animals and plants. New construction, projected to be finished in 2020 - will have to visit again to see what is new! If we lived in the area, this would be a regular hang out and hiking destination. I had visited the Living Desert somewhere in my past, but I don't recall any animals. I recall this as being a plant museum but the combination of plants and animals is fantastic.

We live in San Diego, so inevitably we were comparing this with the San Diego Zoo and the San Diego Safari Park.

The San Diego Zoo is massive compared to this and has a much, much larger catalogue of animals (and plants for that matter). But the animals here were, for the most part, well displayed in spacious outdoor areas that looked less like jail and more like the natural setting seen at Safari Park - and yet remained accessible.

We heard excellent Keeper Talks at the Cheetah enclosure and the African Wild Dog enclosure.

We particularly liked the Giraffe enclosure (but I'm partial to those animals anyway). Seeing the Giraffes "necking" with the sharp, clear mountains as a backdrop was amazing.

If we had had more time, I would have liked to return to see the Christmas lights.

Docents were all very helpful. I don't know what it's like at peak periods, but when we were there (December 7) it was not the elbow throwing crowd scene that the San Diego Zoo can become.

If we lived closer, we'd certainly become members.

Negatives: There were some very large vultures (African?) which were in a very small, flightless enclosure. Food choices were slim.

Living Desert Zoo and Gardens and So Much More!

This is such a special experience! Placed in a very natural setting, this garden and zoo can entertain for hours. From your toddler animal lover to those wanting an interesting hike, you won’t be disappointed in your visit. As of this writing, there was a giraffe feeding for an additional fee, lorikeet feeding and camel rides, also for an additional fee. There are presentations on different animals at posted times throughout the day. You may visit some animals you haven’t seen before! Be sure to look closely at the rugged mountain terrain in hopes of spotting mountain goats. Hiking through the gardens is invigorating and pleasant with different plant specifies well identified. There are multiple options for food and drinks and benches throughout the areas if you brought your own snacks and drinks. There is a shuttle with a guide if you want to get an overview before heading out to your favorite areas on foot.. For those lucky enough to be able to visit frequently, annual passes are available, including couple and family passes, each with their own benefits. AAA discounts available at the ticket window. Free parking. Check temps before your visit. Summer can be hot, hot, hot during the day, but October-May is wonderful.

Don’t miss the reptile and rattlesnake exhibit just to the left of the entrance - small but cool.

My wife and I always wanted to hike the Eisenhower Trail but didn’t want to pay to enter the zoo. This year we decided to bite the bullet and pay the park entrance so we could get to the trailhead. Continues to be the best Living Desert Zoo and Gardens

We travel to Palm Springs twice a year and look forward to visiting the Living Desert Zoo and Gardens in Palm Desert 2-3 times during our stay. A beautiful 1,200 acre desert park setting with easy paved walking paths and even trams for easy transportation. The zoo and desert gardens promotes desert conservation and offers splendid views of exotic and rare animals including Mexican Wolves, Mountain lion, cheetahs, jaguar, leopards, Desert Bighorn Sheep, Great Horned owl, Golden Eagle, roadrunners, hawks, falcons, coyotes, foxes, giraffes, camels, snakes, tortoises, and many others. The Living Desert Zoo has various wildlife shows and even a Carousel and Merry Go Round. Hours are 9:00AM-5:00PM, but Members can enter the park at 7:00AM. A great facility for families and people of all ages.

I found the African section particularly interesting since the desert setting seemed more natural for the animals. The staff provides scheduled chats on specific animals which provides an overview on the animal. There are shuttles travelling around the grounds if you need a lift. We visited yesterday with our 9 year old and 3 year old. Very impressed. Although it was 100 degrees, there was plenty of shade and benches to sit on. The animals and habitats were very well taken care of and the grounds were so clean. The giraffes were adorable and there were great viewing areas. We did not have time to visit the animal hospital or attend any of the chats, so will definitely return for that. I visited the zoo when it was 100 degrees outside, so, understandably, most of the animals were resting and not moving around. The giraffes were very active, though, as they were being fed. I was very impressed by the large amount of room each animal has to move. Each animal really does have its own mini habitat at the park, and that was lovely to see. My favorite part of the park, other than the giraffes, was the animal hospital. A volunteer docent showed me around the hospital and told me about how the zoo brings animals in from all over to provide them proper medical care. Some animals are then released back into the wild, but others are not able to survive outside the zoo. The docent also explained how the hospital is helping to increase the numbers of endangered species. This zoo does amazing work to bring awareness to animal conservation and rehabilitation. I just wish I could've visited when doctors were performing a procedure!

Here are a couple tips...If you are a AAA member, show your card for a $2 discount at the admission window. Also, I recommend walking the park rather than taking the tram. The loop through the park is only 1.5 miles, so, unless you are physically challenged or the weather is too hot, walking the park should be very doable.

There are lots of keepers about and happy to answer questions even when they are not doing a talk and clearly care a lot about the animals. The garden part rates a five. Beautifully maintained desert gardens with plants properly and frequently identified make wandering through the park a joy. The animal enclosures seemed somewhat small, especially for those animals that naturally have a large range. They did seem to be in good physical condition. It is a botonical garden and a zoo that focuses on the deserts of the Southwest. It's beautiful, kid friendly with a discovery center geared to the little kids and the really neat playground. There is even a carousel which runs from October to May or June because the summer is just too hot to run it then. They are only open from 8:00am to 1:30 in the summer again because of the heat. There is a trolley with numerous stops and on/off privileges all day for only $6.00 which makes everything accessible for everybody. The Living Desert is well equipped with wee-placed restrooms, benches, food kiosks and many, many drinking fountains. Programs are scheduled throughout the day giving opportunities for up close and personal contact with some of the critters. I got to hold a snake. Honestly, you should just go. It's even reasonably priced and many hotels have discount tickets available.

I had been here so many years ago and hardly even remembered anythig about it so I thought I would check it out again to see what changed if anything. OMG!!! Was I pleasantly surprised that first off they are doing a trial where they are open on Saturday evenings only thru September from 7pm-10pm. They call it Safari Nights and each night they feature a different theme. (ex. Family Movie Night, Wildlife Wonder Shows, Tequila and Taco Night and Oktoberfest) Hopefully this is successful for them because it was amazing to see this place at night. I saw so many animals out in the enclosures because it was not so hot like it is in the day. I went alone but wasn't for long because I came across the most remarkable and well educated in her field zoo employee (thank you, Amanda) I would have not seen a quarter of what she shared with me on my own. We also were joined by a group of 3 ladies from Canada, they made the tour even more memorable. Amanda showed me every big cat and little ones too, this was her expertise. The zoo is so fortunate to have such a dedicated, so well educated in her field, kind, caring and thoughtful employee. TIP: Go to the North American side of park first, it is only open for the first hour because the area is not lit. Then go to the Africa side. If you don't you will miss the cats. They also have a very large Model train display just before the exit, it is not to missed either! I will definitely return.

One of the best zoos I have been to!

I really liked this zoo! I loved the fact that because it is so hot in Palm Springs, only animals which are suited to that climate are kept there. As soon as we walked in we were greeted by a zoo worker who was holding a leopard gecko. She told us all about the species, the individual she was holding and my nephew got to stoke her. You can feed the giraffes which is a great interactive activity for both children and adults I would say! The enclosures were very spacious and appeared to be very natural. I was particularly impressed with the big horn sheep enclosure! The zoo contained animals I had never seen before such as a mountain lion which made the experience more memorable for me. A land train runs around the zoo for visitors should you find the heat too intense to walk in. There are lots of wild animals to be seen around the zoo too with it being in a desert environment. We saw lots of lizards and even a red racer snake which was very cool! If you like animals and are in the Palm Springs area you should definitely visit Living Desert as it is one of the best zoos I have ever been to!

I've been to The Living Desert many times since we purchased our family pass. Regular visits to the toddler play days and strolls around the park during the holiday Wild Lights.
